runs.text: Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Ask students to look at the picture and tell what they can learn about a bakery from the picture.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
means the amount, or the number, of something.
of cookies is needed for the party.
Ask: What might you need a large
Have students whisper-read the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word that describes Grandpas cakes. (tasty)
Who took over the bakery when Grandpa retired? Find the sentence that answers the question.
Why did the family need to make a large quantity of bread when they sold to stores?
Where would you go to buy baked goods? What would you buy there?
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.

, it makes money for the business owners. Have students tell what they think
routine. You will prompt students to use this term to talk about the text.
Have students whisper-read the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Which word describes beaches that need cleaning up? (dirty)
What do some nonprofits do for animals? Find the sentence that answers the question.
Can a nonprofit organization enhance a persons life? Why or why not?
Think about the nonprofits that you read about in this text. Which one would you like to help the most? Why?
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Have students whisperread each sentence. Then ask them to chorally read it.
Have them point to and read those words to a partner.
Have students write a sentence using the word
. Have students read the sentence to a partner.
Remind students that end punctuation can help readers tell what kind of sentence they are reading.
Review the kind of sentences that end with a period, question mark, and an exclamation point. Have students compare the end punctuation for sentences 13.
Then discuss the different types of punctuation:
The question mark shows that the sentence is a question. The exclamation point shows that the sentence shows excitement. The period shows that the sentence is a statement.
Follow a similar procedure with sentences 4, 5, and 10. Then have students read the three sentences aloud with you.
Read the title. Explain that this text asks questions that are riddles. Each riddle contains clues about the answer that is always about money.

For the first reading, read the riddles and have students read the answers. Then pair students to reread the riddles. Partners can switch roles during the rereadings: one reads the riddle, and the other reads the answer.
Prompt students to find and circle all the words in the riddles with suffixes
. Then have students chorally read the circled words. Ask students questions about the text to confirm understanding.
Say each word, guide students to write it, then proceed to the next word in the sentence.
Provide supports for words that are
completely comprised of the phonics skills students have learned.
These supports include sound boxes, tapping the sounds, and so on.
Provide supports for the high-frequency words students have learned.
When completed, have students read the entire
Self-Correct: Write the sentences on the board, and have students self-correct. Take note of errors on each students Student Observation Form.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to the word.
Explain that students will read about different ways people pay for things in the USA.

Have students whisper-read the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word that tells the speed at which interest can add up. (slowly)
What are some of the ways you can
things? Find sentences that answer this question.
How is using a check like using a credit card? How is it different?
Is money important to you? Why or why not?
Have students whisperread each sentence. Then ask them to chorally read it.
Have students circle words with the suffix -
. Have them point to and read those words to a partner.
Have students write a sentence using the word
. Have them read the sentence to a partner.
Identify and discuss different types of sentences by looking at end punctuation.
Help students identify statements (sentences 4, 5, 6, 8, 9, 10), questions (sentences 1, 3, 7) and exclamations (sentence 2).
Discuss the purpose of each type of sentence and ask students to make up additional examples.

Read the title. Explain that authors often include charts in informational articles to present important information in a clear and brief way. This article includes a chart to show the value of different kinds of currency, or money, all around the world.
Guide students through a reading of the selection, including the chart.
Prompt students to share what they notice and wonder when viewing the chart.

Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word. This is an on-level selection. It is provided to gauge where students are in their reading progress toward grade-level goals. Students might need to listen and follow along with the e-book for support before they read the book on their own.
Explain to students that they will read an opinion text about whether kids should or should not get an allowance.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
means to talk someone into doing something.
me to go to the party.
a friend to come to your home for a visit?
Have students whisperread the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word that means every week. (weekly)
What does it mean to put money aside for a rainy day? Find the sentences that answer the question.
Which reason do you think is best to
people that kids should get an allowance? Why is this a good reason?
Do you think kids should get an allowance? Why or why not?
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that this informational text is about how people used to trade to get the goods and services they needed.

When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Which word describes the apple that might be traded? (crunchy)
to money that lets people get the things they need? Find the sentence that answers the question.
What do you think were some of the professions, or jobs, that traded for their services long ago?
Would you rather trade or pay money to get something? Why?
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
